channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Times Video Presents: ‘To Kill a Sparrow’
item.description: An Afghan woman who was betrothed to ensure family peace becomes the subject of a documentary as she struggles to avoid the life her father had intended for her.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Hong Kong Protester Arrested, Accused of Inciting Others to Confront Police
item.description: In the first such arrest since the protest started, the Hong Kong police said the protester, 23, used an online message board to encourage others.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG

item.title: Swedish Navy Hunts for Source of Underwater Signals
item.description: A Swedish newspaper said the military intercepted a radio transmission from a Russian submarine that was perhaps stranded near Stockholm.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Foul Air Deters Some, But Not All, Marathoners in Beijing
item.description: Organizers of the 34th Beijing International Marathon didn’t cancel on Sunday despite air pollution readings that hit levels where the government urges people to wear face masks and avoid outdoor activities.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Runners passing a haze-enshrouded Tiananmen Gate on Sunday during the 2014 Beijing International Marathon.

item.title: International Education: British Universities Get Good News
item.description: A study released this month says that by 2024, Britain will add 83,000 foreign graduate students to the nearly quarter-million it hosted in 2013.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE

item.title: Indian Leader’s Party Gains Seats in Key State Elections
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party won the most seats in two important Indian state elections where votes were counted on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don't Make a Bad Deal With Iran
item.description: The Islamic Republic is the greatest threat to global security; it must not be allowed to have nuclear weapons.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By YUVAL STEINITZ

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: What China Means by ‘Rule of Law’
item.description: Every reform made or promised in China provides an opening.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL GEWIRTZ

item.title: Pope Francis Beatifies Pope Paul VI
item.description: The ceremony closed a two-week assembly of bishops convened by Francis to discuss the church’s attitude toward the complexities faced by many families.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Power Up: For South Korea, Host of League of Legends Championship, E-Sports Is National Pastime
item.description: The extent to which video games have become part of mainstream culture in South Korea may be a sign of things to come in the West.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL MOZUR
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of gamers playing League of Legends at an Internet cafe, known as a PC bang, on Saturday in Seoul, South Korea.

item.title: Gunfire Exchanged on Korean Boundary
item.description: South Korea said troops from the North had approached the demarcation line and there was a brief exchange of gunfire between guard posts on both sides.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: At Least 22 Reportedly Killed in Attack in Western China
item.description: Four men with knives and explosives targeted the police and merchants at a market in Xinjiang, Radio Free Asia said.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Some Victims in Kunming Clash Were Burned to Death, Government Says
item.description: The grim government report adds to the widespread shock over the death toll in the confrontation between developers and local residents in a rural area of Kunming in southern China.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Residents guard the entrance to their village in Kunming, the capital of Yunnan province.

item.title: Veliky Novgorod Journal: Where Mud Is Archaeological Gold, Russian History Grew on Trees
item.description: More than 1,000 birch-bark documents have been uncovered after being preserved for hundreds of years in the magical mud of Veliky Novgorod.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boy left a message and drawing on a birch scroll in Old Novgorod language, a precursor to Russian. The scroll was dug from the preservative mud of Veliky Novgorod.

item.title: Mexico Finds Many Corpses, but Not Lost 43
item.description: Residents of Iguala, Mexico, searching for students who disappeared after a clash with the police, have not found them, but they have found mass graves.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Janet Jarman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents at a possible grave site on the outskirts of Iguala, Mexco, where 43 students disappeared after a clash with the police.

item.title: New Clashes in Hong Kong After Activists Retake Streets
item.description: Both sides reported injuries in confrontations after demonstrators regained ground earlier seized by police, as the pro-democracy protests entered their fourth week.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Protesters and barricades in the Mong Kok neighborhood on Saturday after further clashes with the police erupted overnight.

item.title: A Train Ride Through Time: From Iraq’s Checkered Past Into an Uncertain Future
item.description: Grand ambitions to restore the country’s run-down train services to their former glory have been impeded by Islamic State’s advances.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A young girl looks out of the newer, Chinese-built train.

item.title: For Japan, Small Gesture Holds Great Importance
item.description: Japanese officials see a gesture between Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan and President Xi Jinping of China as the start of repairing relations.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan.

item.title: Planner of Pop Concert Found Dead in South Korea
item.description: A day after 16 people were killed in an accident at an outdoor concert in South Korea, a man involved in the show’s planning died in an apparent suicide, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: New at the Helm of Indonesia’s Government: A Common Man
item.description: Born in a slum in Central Java, Joko Widodo takes office as president of the world’s fourth most populous nation on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joko Widodo will be the first Indonesian president not to come from the political or military elite.

item.title: Hopes Wane for Finding Missing Trekkers in Nepal
item.description: By Saturday, the death toll from an intense snowstorm and avalanches had reached 39, according to a Tourism Ministry official.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR and BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: After Delay, Iraq Appoints Two to Posts for Security
item.description: Parliament approved two appointees to lead ministries responsible for the nation’s security forces, vacancies that had highlighted sectarian tensions and generated weeks of negotiations.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Bermuda Mending After Hurricane Gonzalo
item.description: Although the Category 2 hurricane hit Bermuda directly, the small island was spared major damage and the police said there were no fatalities.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: No Consensus at Vatican as Synod Ends
item.description: Bishops at a closely watched synod did not agree on what to say about gay people and whether to give communion to divorced and remarried Catholics.
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican on Saturday as a two-week assembly drew to a close.

item.title: Blunt U.S. Appeal Encourages Huangs, Couple Held in Qatar
item.description: Matthew and Grace Huang, who were arrested after the death of their adopted daughter, are cautiously optimistic that they may finally be permitted to go home.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grace and Matthew Huang were arrested after the death of their adopted daughter, and accused of being child traffickers.
